C108_04.E4440_02: mysterious death in 1849, Griswold wrote an unsympathetic obituary.

C108_04.E4440_01: Rufus Wilmot Griswold February 13, 1815 August 27, 1857 was an
C108_04.E4440_02: American anthologist, editor, poet, and critic. Born in Vermont,
C108_04.E4440_03: Griswold left home when he was 15. He worked as a journalist, editor,
C108_04.E4440_04: and critic in Philadelphia, New York City, and elsewhere. He built up
C108_04.E4440_05: a strong literary reputation, in part due to his 1842 collection The

C108_04.E4440_01: Poets and Poetry of America. This anthology, the most comprehensive of
C108_04.E4440_02: its time, included what he deemed the best examples of American
C108_04.E4440_03: poetry. He produced revised versions and similar anthologies for the
C108_04.E4440_04: remainder of his life, although many of the poets he promoted have
C108_04.E4440_05: since faded into obscurity. Many writers hoped to have their work

C108_04.E4440_01: included in one of these editions, although they commented harshly on
C108_04.E4440_02: Griswold's abrasive character. Griswold was married three times: his
C108_04.E4440_03: first wife died young, his second marriage ended in a public and
C108_04.E4440_04: controversial divorce, and his third wife left him after the previous

C108_04.E4440_01: Edgar Allan Poe, whose poetry had been included in Griswold's
C108_04.E4440_02: anthology, published a critical response that questioned which poets
C108_04.E4440_03: were included. This began a rivalry which grew when Griswold succeeded
C108_04.E4440_04: Poe as editor of Graham's Magazine at a higher salary than Poe's.
C108_04.E4440_05: Later, the two competed for the attention of poet Frances Sargent

C108_04.E4440_01: Osgood. They never reconciled their differences and, after Poe's
C108_04.E4440_02: mysterious death in 1849, Griswold wrote an unsympathetic obituary.
C108_04.E4440_03: Claiming to be Poe's chosen literary executor, he began a campaign to
C108_04.E4440_04: harm Poe's reputation that lasted until his own death eight years

C108_04.E4440_01: Griswold considered himself an expert in American poetry and was an
C108_04.E4440_02: early proponent of its inclusion on the school curriculum. He also
C108_04.E4440_03: supported the introduction of copyright legislation, speaking to
C108_04.E4440_04: Congress on behalf of the publishing industry, although he was not
C108_04.E4440_05: above pirating other people's work. A fellow editor remarked, "even

C108_04.E4440_01: while haranguing the loudest, [he] is purloining the fastest".[1]
C108_04.E4440_02: Griswold was born on February 13, 1815,[2] in Vermont, near Rutland,
C108_04.E4440_03: and raised a strict Calvinist[3] in the hamlet of Benson.[4] He was
C108_04.E4440_04: the twelfth of fourteen children and his father was a farmer and
C108_04.E4440_05: shoemaker.[4] In 1822, the family sold the Benson farm and moved to

C108_04.E4440_01: nearby Hubbardton.[5] As a child, Griswold was complex, unpredictable,
C108_04.E4440_02: and reckless.[6] He left home when he was 15, calling himself a
C108_04.E4440_03: "solitary soul, wandering through the world, a homeless, joyless
C108_04.E4440_05: Griswold moved to Albany, New York, to live with a 22-year-old

C108_04.E4440_01: flute-playing journalist named George C. Foster, a writer best known
C108_04.E4440_02: for his work New-York by Gas-Light.[4] Griswold lived with Foster
C108_04.E4440_03: until he was 17, and the two may have had a romantic relationship.[7]
C108_04.E4440_04: When Griswold moved away, Foster wrote to him begging him to return,
C108_04.E4440_05: signing his letter "come to me if you love me".[8] Griswold attempted

C108_04.E4440_01: to enroll at the Rensselaer School in 1830, but was not allowed to
C108_04.E4440_02: take any classes after he was caught attempting to play a prank on a
C108_04.E4440_05: After a brief spell as a printer's apprentice, Griswold moved to

C108_04.E4440_01: Syracuse where,[7] with some friends, he started a newspaper called
C108_04.E4440_02: The Porcupine. This publication purposefully targeted locals for what
C108_04.E4440_03: was later remembered as merely malicious critique.[10]
C108_04.E4440_04: He moved to New York City in 1836 and, in March of that year, was
C108_04.E4440_05: introduced to 19-year-old Caroline Searles, whom he later married.[11]

C108_04.E4440_01: He was employed as an editor for various publications in the New York
C108_04.E4440_02: area. In October, he considered running for office as a Whig but did
C108_04.E4440_03: not receive the party's support.[12] In 1837 he was licensed as a
C108_04.E4440_04: Baptist clergyman, although he never had a permanent congregation.[13]
C108_04.E4440_05: Griswold married Caroline on August 12, 1837,[14] and the couple had

C108_04.E4440_01: two daughters. Following the birth of cargo description description
